name: NPR
text: Three skiers died in two avalanches that struck Colorado mountains in recent days, in snow that avalanche experts warn is the most unstable it has been in years. https://t.co/vYjzKD9IXd

name: NPR
text: A top employee of Dominion Voting Systems is suing the Trump campaign, a number of campaign surrogates and pro-Trump media outlets for defamation. https://t.co/Y1jIKIkyqM

name: NPR
text: #JustIn: President Trump has granted clemency to 20 people, including former campaign adviser George Papadopoulos and former Rep. Duncan Hunter. https://t.co/pv3Qnik132

name: NPR
text: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit against Walmart on Tuesday, alleging that the retail giant unlawfully dispensed controlled substances from pharmacies it operated nationwide. https://t.co/f2yH0MX5BO

name: NPR
text: #JustIn: President Trump is slamming a $900 billion COVID-19 relief package, calling it a "disgrace." https://t.co/HrLgg52112

name: NPR
text: One of the most prestigious newspapers in the midwestern United States issued an apology for what it called "both action and inaction in shaping and misshaping" the history of Missouri's most populous city and its surrounding region. https://t.co/gfMEOMrV8m

name: NPR
text: The oil and plastic industry, which makes the pellets, says it has programs in place to prevent any spills. But NPR and PBS Frontline found top officials have known about the problem for decades. https://t.co/jDKoS1lmnX

name: NPR
text: For the second time in a month, a black man was shot and killed by authorities in Columbus, Ohio. The officer didn't activate his body camera until afterward. City officials have again asked the local U.S. Attorney's Office to investigate. @WOSUnews https://t.co/G5v1o1Fd8y

name: NPR
text: Israeli politics is once again in turmoil: parliament has dissolved and Israel will hold yet another election expected on March 23. It will be Israel's fourth national vote in the span of two years. https://t.co/Ro7exTOou4

name: NPR
text: RT @tamarakeithNPR: Pelosi agreeing with Trump here. This potentially sets up a very big test of Trump power over Senate Republicans. ...which arguably is waning. There's probably an adage about not asking questions you don't want the answer to. https://t.co/ae3Go7zRzC

name: NPR
text: Dr. Deborah Birx, one of the nation's highest-ranking infectious disease experts, suggested on Tuesday she'll likely retire ... soonish. https://t.co/qEI5iAPJ8t

name: NPR
text: "If we have another surge after Christmas and New Year's like we did after Thanksgiving, it will completely break our hospitals," Tennessee's health commissioner said this week. https://t.co/VUOR0FQ16k

name: NPR
text:
Among his comments Tuesday, President-elect Biden sharply criticized President Trump over the widespread cyberattack through the federal government.

"This assault happened on Donald Trump's watch when he wasn't watching," Joe Biden said. https://t.co/PRhn2sAH5v

name: NPR
text: In The Before Times, this is what it took to get those holiday packages to doorsteps in time for Christmas morning. https://t.co/124XRFeGz3

name: NPR
text:
As President Trump continues to claim falsely that he — and not President-elect Biden — won the Nov. 3 election, the next date that looms on the electoral calendar is Jan. 6.

That's when Congress meets to formally count the Electoral College votes. https://t.co/5MCYM9bRfq

name: NPR
text: A police officer in Columbus, Ohio, was temporarily removed from duty pending the outcome of criminal and internal investigations following the fatal shooting of an apparently unnamed Black man early Tuesday. https://t.co/gsjATANeUt

name: NPR
text: France has reopened its borders to travelers and truck drivers from the United Kingdom who show proof of a negative coronavirus test taken within the previous 72 hours. https://t.co/20qyzYqIBi

name: NPR
text:
The wheels on the nation's buses aren't going round and round very much these days.

Demand for bus travel has fallen by more than 80% during the pandemic, as public health authorities urge people to avoid travel where possible. https://t.co/AqvwvFosNY

name: NPR
text: The Trump administration says it has reached a deal with Pfizer to buy an additional 100 million doses of the company's COVID-19 vaccine, effectively doubling the federal government's supply from Pfizer. https://t.co/FPdk3cFUwL

name: NPR
text: Eric Coomer, who oversees product and strategy for Dominion,  said in addition to his own information, the personal addresses of everyone from his family to his ex-girlfriends have been posted online. Some have also received threatening letters. https://t.co/bbnfvdxCat

name: NPR
text:
Lorraine Rogge and her husband, travel the country in a recreational vehicle, a well-earned adventure in retirement. 

Recently a visit to a for profit medical center left her with a nightmare $12,387 lab fee. https://t.co/wo7vGoKgPm

name: NPR
text: Tasked with writing a pandemic-era holiday song, Adam Weiner of Low Cut Connie thought back to a journal entry he wrote nearly 20 years ago, while working as a perfume spritzer at a local mall. https://t.co/1ZNdbwbwfQ

name: NPR
text: Top leaders and rank-and-file members of Congress are taking part in the first round of COVID-19 vaccinations, a move that could accelerate plans for Congress to return to business as usual. But not all lawmakers agree on who should get priority. https://t.co/PhbjKHdTSS

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: "I've been threatened more times than I could even count."

An official with Dominion Voting Systems is in hiding. It's just the latest example of how people's lives are being upended and potentially ruined by the flurry of disinformation this year. https://t.co/p4qgLGMNm7

name: NPR
text:
It's no secret that inhaling smoke is bad for your lungs. But now, scientists are suggesting smoke may also carry and spread infectious diseases. 

A theory based on research found wildfire smoke is teeming with thousands of species of microorganisms. https://t.co/ZHEWbYx4nD

name: NPR
text:
In Yemen today, 1 in 5 children are severely malnourished, according to U.N. reports.

"Losing my child while I am watching is breaking my heart," says Mohammed Yousuf as he tries to calm his crying son. https://t.co/UpLFekrXbd

name: NPR
text: Antarctica is no longer the only continent free of the pandemic. Thirty-six people stationed at the General Bernardo O'Higgins Riquelme Antarctic base had tested positive for the virus, Chilean officials said this week.  https://t.co/SlN5m7sWOj

name: NPR
text:
RT @MilesParks: An employee of the voting machine company Dominion has been living in hiding for the past month. His life may never be the same after the past month's conspiracy theories.

From @BenteBirkeland and me:

https://t.co/uoniTL9ReQ

name: NPR
text:
Los Angeles County Supervisor Sheila Kuehl's district sweeps from Santa Monica to the San Fernando Valley. She's turned to Facebook to post ads that urged people to wear masks.

Now as spikes in COVID-19 cases surge, her ads are being flagged by Facebook. https://t.co/vJ7j6Uy9Ag

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: President Trump has followed through on his threats to veto the annual defense bill, triggering plans for Congress to return from their holiday break to potentially override him. https://t.co/aQ474QBsK3

name: NPR
text: These are the best songs of 2020, as selected by The World Cafe staff. The list features songs from Jason Isbell, Bonny Light Horseman, and Kathleen Edwards. https://t.co/2TCShkrEf5
